001package com.github.tommyettinger.colorful;
002
003/**
004 * Some alternative approximations to sin(), cos(), asin(), acos(), and atan2(), including the option to measure
005 * most values in turns instead of radians (where 1 turn equals 2pi radians). The convention here is to have methods
006 * that take input in turns or produce output in turns use a {@code _} suffix, like {@link #sin_(double)}, for turns to
007 * never be returned as a negative value but for negative turn inputs to be accepted, and for the output type to match
008 * the input type (float input gives float output, double input gives double output).
009 * Created by Tommy Ettinger on 8/6/2019.
010 */
011public class TrigTools {
012
013    /**
014     * A fairly-close approximation of {@link Math#sin(double)} that can be significantly faster (between 8x and 80x
015     * faster sin() calls in benchmarking; if you have access to libGDX you should consider its sometimes-more-precise
016     * and sometimes-faster MathUtils.sin() method. Because this method doesn't rely on a
017     * lookup table, where libGDX's MathUtils does, applications that have a bottleneck on memory may perform better
018     * with this method than with MathUtils. Takes the same arguments Math.sin() does, so one angle in radians,
019     * which may technically be any double (but this will lose precision on fairly large doubles, such as those that are
020     * larger than {@link Long#MAX_VALUE}, because those doubles themselves will lose precision at that scale). This
021     * is closely related to a cubic sway, but the shape of the output when graphed is almost identical to
022     * sin(). The difference between the result of this method and {@link Math#sin(double)} should be under 0.0011 at
023     * all points between -pi and pi, with an average difference of about 0.0005; not all points have been checked for
024     * potentially higher errors, though.
025     * <br>
026     * The error for this double version is extremely close to the float version, {@link #sin(float)}, so you should
027     * choose based on what type you have as input and/or want to return rather than on quality concerns. Coercion
028     * between float and double takes about as long as this method normally takes to run (or longer), so if you have
029     * floats you should usually use methods that take floats (or return floats, if assigning the result to a float),
030     * and likewise for doubles.
031     * <br>
032     * The technique for sine approximation is mostly from
033     * <a href="https://web.archive.org/web/20080228213915/http://devmaster.net/forums/showthread.php?t=5784">this archived DevMaster thread</a>,
034     * with credit to "Nick". Changes have been made to accelerate wrapping from any double to the valid input range.
035     * @param radians an angle in radians as a double, often from 0 to pi * 2, though not required to be.
036     * @return the sine of the given angle, as a double between -1.0 and 1.0 (both inclusive)
037     */
038
039    public static double sin(double radians)
040    {
041        radians *= 0.6366197723675814;
042        final long floor = (radians >= 0.0 ? (long) radians : (long) radians - 1L) & -2L;
043        radians -= floor;
044        radians *= 2.0 - radians;
045        return radians * (-0.775 - 0.225 * radians) * ((floor & 2L) - 1L);
046    }
047
048    /**
049     * A fairly-close approximation of {@link Math#cos(double)} that can be significantly faster (between 8x and 80x
050     * faster cos() calls in benchmarking; if you have access to libGDX you should consider its sometimes-more-precise
051     * and sometimes-faster MathUtils.cos() method. Because this method doesn't rely on a
052     * lookup table, where libGDX's MathUtils does, applications that have a bottleneck on memory may perform better
053     * with this method than with MathUtils. Takes the same arguments Math.cos() does, so one angle in radians,
054     * which may technically be any double (but this will lose precision on fairly large doubles, such as those that are
055     * larger than {@link Long#MAX_VALUE}, because those doubles themselves will lose precision at that scale). This
056     * is closely related to a cubic sway, but the shape of the output when graphed is almost identical to
057     * cos(). The difference between the result of this method and {@link Math#cos(double)} should be under 0.0011 at
058     * all points between -pi and pi, with an average difference of about 0.0005; not all points have been checked for
059     * potentially higher errors, though.
060     * <br>
061     * The error for this double version is extremely close to the float version, {@link #cos(float)}, so you should
062     * choose based on what type you have as input and/or want to return rather than on quality concerns. Coercion
063     * between float and double takes about as long as this method normally takes to run (or longer), so if you have
064     * floats you should usually use methods that take floats (or return floats, if assigning the result to a float),
065     * and likewise for doubles.
066     * <br>
067     * The technique for cosine approximation is mostly from
068     * <a href="https://web.archive.org/web/20080228213915/http://devmaster.net/forums/showthread.php?t=5784">this archived DevMaster thread</a>,
069     * with credit to "Nick". Changes have been made to accelerate wrapping from any double to the valid input range.
070     * @param radians an angle in radians as a double, often from 0 to pi * 2, though not required to be.
071     * @return the cosine of the given angle, as a double between -1.0 and 1.0 (both inclusive)
072     */
073    public static double cos(double radians)
074    {
075        radians = radians * 0.6366197723675814 + 1.0;
076        final long floor = (radians >= 0.0 ? (long) radians : (long) radians - 1L) & -2L;
077        radians -= floor;
078        radians *= 2.0 - radians;
079        return radians * (-0.775 - 0.225 * radians) * ((floor & 2L) - 1L);
080    }
081
082    /**
083     * A fairly-close approximation of {@link Math#sin(double)} that can be significantly faster (between 8x and 80x
084     * faster sin() calls in benchmarking, and both takes and returns floats; if you have access to libGDX you should
085     * consider its more-precise and sometimes-faster MathUtils.sin() method. Because this method doesn't rely on a
086     * lookup table, where libGDX's MathUtils does, applications that have a bottleneck on memory may perform better
087     * with this method than with MathUtils. Takes the same arguments Math.sin() does, so one angle in radians,
088     * which may technically be any float (but this will lose precision on fairly large floats, such as those that are
089     * larger than {@link Integer#MAX_VALUE}, because those floats themselves will lose precision at that scale). This
090     * is closely related to a cubic sway, but the shape of the output when graphed is almost identical to
091     * sin(). The difference between the result of this method and {@link Math#sin(double)} should be under 0.0011 at
092     * all points between -pi and pi, with an average difference of about 0.0005; not all points have been checked for
093     * potentially higher errors, though.
094     * <br>
095     * The error for this float version is extremely close to the double version, {@link #sin(double)}, so you should
096     * choose based on what type you have as input and/or want to return rather than on quality concerns. Coercion
097     * between float and double takes about as long as this method normally takes to run (or longer), so if you have
098     * floats you should usually use methods that take floats (or return floats, if assigning the result to a float),
099     * and likewise for doubles.
100     * <br>
101     * The technique for sine approximation is mostly from
102     * <a href="https://web.archive.org/web/20080228213915/http://devmaster.net/forums/showthread.php?t=5784">this archived DevMaster thread</a>,
103     * with credit to "Nick". Changes have been made to accelerate wrapping from any float to the valid input range.
104     * @param radians an angle in radians as a float, often from 0 to pi * 2, though not required to be.
105     * @return the sine of the given angle, as a float between -1f and 1f (both inclusive)
106     */
107    public static float sin(float radians)
108    {
109        radians *= 0.6366197723675814f;
110        final int floor = (radians >= 0.0 ? (int) radians : (int) radians - 1) & -2;
111        radians -= floor;
112        radians *= 2f - radians;
113        return radians * (-0.775f - 0.225f * radians) * ((floor & 2) - 1);
114    }
115
116    /**
117     * A fairly-close approximation of {@link Math#cos(double)} that can be significantly faster (between 8x and 80x
118     * faster cos() calls in benchmarking, and both takes and returns floats; if you have access to libGDX you should
119     * consider its more-precise and sometimes-faster MathUtils.cos() method. Because this method doesn't rely on a
120     * lookup table, where libGDX's MathUtils does, applications that have a bottleneck on memory may perform better
121     * with this method than with MathUtils. Takes the same arguments Math.cos() does, so one angle in radians,
122     * which may technically be any float (but this will lose precision on fairly large floats, such as those that are
123     * larger than {@link Integer#MAX_VALUE}, because those floats themselves will lose precision at that scale). This
124     * is closely related to a cubic sway, but the shape of the output when graphed is almost identical to
125     * cos(). The difference between the result of this method and {@link Math#cos(double)} should be under 0.0011 at
126     * all points between -pi and pi, with an average difference of about 0.0005; not all points have been checked for
127     * potentially higher errors, though.
128     * <br>
129     * The error for this float version is extremely close to the double version, {@link #cos(double)}, so you should
130     * choose based on what type you have as input and/or want to return rather than on quality concerns. Coercion
131     * between float and double takes about as long as this method normally takes to run (or longer), so if you have
132     * floats you should usually use methods that take floats (or return floats, if assigning the result to a float),
133     * and likewise for doubles.
134     * <br>
135     * The technique for cosine approximation is mostly from
136     * <a href="https://web.archive.org/web/20080228213915/http://devmaster.net/forums/showthread.php?t=5784">this archived DevMaster thread</a>,
137     * with credit to "Nick". Changes have been made to accelerate wrapping from any float to the valid input range.
138     * @param radians an angle in radians as a float, often from 0 to pi * 2, though not required to be.
139     * @return the cosine of the given angle, as a float between -1f and 1f (both inclusive)
140     */
141    public static float cos(float radians)
142    {
143        radians = radians * 0.6366197723675814f + 1f;
144        final int floor = (radians >= 0.0 ? (int) radians : (int) radians - 1) & -2;
145        radians -= floor;
146        radians *= 2f - radians;
147        return radians * (-0.775f - 0.225f * radians) * ((floor & 2) - 1);
148    }
149
150    /**
151     * A variation on {@link Math#sin(double)} that takes its input as a fraction of a turn instead of in radians; one
152     * turn is equal to 360 degrees or two*PI radians. This can be useful as a building block for other measurements;
153     * to make a sine method that takes its input in grad (with 400 grad equal to 360 degrees), you would just divide
154     * the grad value by 400.0 (or multiply it by 0.0025) and pass it to this method. Similarly for binary degrees, also
155     * called brad (with 256 brad equal to 360 degrees), you would divide by 256.0 or multiply by 0.00390625 before
156     * passing that value here. The brad case is especially useful because you can use a byte for any brad values, and
157     * adding up those brad values will wrap correctly (256 brad goes back to 0) while keeping perfect precision for the
158     * results (you still divide by 256.0 when you pass the brad value to this method).
159     * <br>
160     * The error for this double version is extremely close to the float version, {@link #sin_(float)}, so you should
161     * choose based on what type you have as input and/or want to return rather than on quality concerns. Coercion
162     * between float and double takes about as long as this method normally takes to run (or longer), so if you have
163     * floats you should usually use methods that take floats (or return floats, if assigning the result to a float),
164     * and likewise for doubles.
165     * <br>
166     * The technique for sine approximation is mostly from
167     * <a href="https://web.archive.org/web/20080228213915/http://devmaster.net/forums/showthread.php?t=5784">this archived DevMaster thread</a>,
168     * with credit to "Nick". Changes have been made to accelerate wrapping from any double to the valid input range.
169     * @param turns an angle as a fraction of a turn as a double, with 0.5 here equivalent to PI radians in {@link #cos(double)}
170     * @return the sine of the given angle, as a double between -1.0 and 1.0 (both inclusive)
171     */
172    public static double sin_(double turns)
173    {
174        turns *= 4.0;
175        final long floor = (turns >= 0.0 ? (long) turns : (long) turns - 1L) & -2L;
176        turns -= floor;
177        turns *= 2.0 - turns;
178        return turns * (-0.775 - 0.225 * turns) * ((floor & 2L) - 1L);
179    }
180
181    /**
182     * A variation on {@link Math#cos(double)} that takes its input as a fraction of a turn instead of in radians; one
183     * turn is equal to 360 degrees or two*PI radians. This can be useful as a building block for other measurements;
184     * to make a cosine method that takes its input in grad (with 400 grad equal to 360 degrees), you would just divide
185     * the grad value by 400.0 (or multiply it by 0.0025) and pass it to this method. Similarly for binary degrees, also
186     * called brad (with 256 brad equal to 360 degrees), you would divide by 256.0 or multiply by 0.00390625 before
187     * passing that value here. The brad case is especially useful because you can use a byte for any brad values, and
188     * adding up those brad values will wrap correctly (256 brad goes back to 0) while keeping perfect precision for the
189     * results (you still divide by 256.0 when you pass the brad value to this method).
190     * <br>
191     * The error for this double version is extremely close to the float version, {@link #cos_(float)}, so you should
192     * choose based on what type you have as input and/or want to return rather than on quality concerns. Coercion
193     * between float and double takes about as long as this method normally takes to run (or longer), so if you have
194     * floats you should usually use methods that take floats (or return floats, if assigning the result to a float),
195     * and likewise for doubles.
196     * <br>
197     * The technique for cosine approximation is mostly from
198     * <a href="https://web.archive.org/web/20080228213915/http://devmaster.net/forums/showthread.php?t=5784">this archived DevMaster thread</a>,
199     * with credit to "Nick". Changes have been made to accelerate wrapping from any double to the valid input range.
200     * @param turns an angle as a fraction of a turn as a double, with 0.5 here equivalent to PI radians in {@link #cos(double)}
201     * @return the cosine of the given angle, as a double between -1.0 and 1.0 (both inclusive)
202     */
203    public static double cos_(double turns)
204    {
205        turns = turns * 4.0 + 1.0;
206        final long floor = (turns >= 0.0 ? (long) turns : (long) turns - 1L) & -2L;
207        turns -= floor;
208        turns *= 2.0 - turns;
209        return turns * (-0.775 - 0.225 * turns) * ((floor & 2L) - 1L);
210    }
211
212    /**
213     * A variation on {@link Math#sin(double)} that takes its input as a fraction of a turn instead of in radians (it
214     * also takes and returns a float); one turn is equal to 360 degrees or two*PI radians. This can be useful as a
215     * building block for other measurements; to make a sine method that takes its input in grad (with 400 grad equal to
216     * 360 degrees), you would just divide the grad value by 400.0 (or multiply it by 0.0025) and pass it to this
217     * method. Similarly for binary degrees, also called brad (with 256 brad equal to 360 degrees), you would divide by
218     * 256.0 or multiply by 0.00390625 before passing that value here. The brad case is especially useful because you
219     * can use a byte for any brad values, and adding up those brad values will wrap correctly (256 brad goes back to 0)
220     * while keeping perfect precision for the results (you still divide by 256.0 when you pass the brad value to this
221     * method).
222     * <br>
223     * The error for this float version is extremely close to the double version, {@link #sin_(double)}, so you should
224     * choose based on what type you have as input and/or want to return rather than on quality concerns. Coercion
225     * between float and double takes about as long as this method normally takes to run (or longer), so if you have
226     * floats you should usually use methods that take floats (or return floats, if assigning the result to a float),
227     * and likewise for doubles.
228     * <br>
229     * The technique for sine approximation is mostly from
230     * <a href="https://web.archive.org/web/20080228213915/http://devmaster.net/forums/showthread.php?t=5784">this archived DevMaster thread</a>,
231     * with credit to "Nick". Changes have been made to accelerate wrapping from any double to the valid input range.
232     * @param turns an angle as a fraction of a turn as a float, with 0.5 here equivalent to PI radians in {@link #cos(double)}
233     * @return the sine of the given angle, as a float between -1.0 and 1.0 (both inclusive)
234     */
235    public static float sin_(float turns)
236    {
237        turns *= 4f;
238        final long floor = (turns >= 0.0 ? (long) turns : (long) turns - 1L) & -2L;
239        turns -= floor;
240        turns *= 2f - turns;
241        return turns * (-0.775f - 0.225f * turns) * ((floor & 2L) - 1L);
242    }
243
244    /**
245     * A variation on {@link Math#cos(double)} that takes its input as a fraction of a turn instead of in radians (it
246     * also takes and returns a float); one turn is equal to 360 degrees or two*PI radians. This can be useful as a
247     * building block for other measurements; to make a cosine method that takes its input in grad (with 400 grad equal
248     * to 360 degrees), you would just divide the grad value by 400.0 (or multiply it by 0.0025) and pass it to this
249     * method. Similarly for binary degrees, also called brad (with 256 brad equal to 360 degrees), you would divide by
250     * 256.0 or multiply by 0.00390625 before passing that value here. The brad case is especially useful because you
251     * can use a byte for any brad values, and adding up those brad values will wrap correctly (256 brad goes back to 0)
252     * while keeping perfect precision for the results (you still divide by 256.0 when you pass the brad value to this
253     * method).
254     * <br>
255     * The error for this float version is extremely close to the float version, {@link #cos_(double)}, so you should
256     * choose based on what type you have as input and/or want to return rather than on quality concerns. Coercion
257     * between float and double takes about as long as this method normally takes to run (or longer), so if you have
258     * floats you should usually use methods that take floats (or return floats, if assigning the result to a float),
259     * and likewise for doubles.
260     * <br>
261     * The technique for cosine approximation is mostly from
262     * <a href="https://web.archive.org/web/20080228213915/http://devmaster.net/forums/showthread.php?t=5784">this archived DevMaster thread</a>,
263     * with credit to "Nick". Changes have been made to accelerate wrapping from any double to the valid input range.
264     * @param turns an angle as a fraction of a turn as a float, with 0.5 here equivalent to PI radians in {@link #cos(double)}
265     * @return the cosine of the given angle, as a float between -1.0 and 1.0 (both inclusive)
266     */
267    public static float cos_(float turns)
268    {
269        turns = turns * 4f + 1f;
270        final long floor = (turns >= 0.0 ? (long) turns : (long) turns - 1L) & -2L;
271        turns -= floor;
272        turns *= 2f - turns;
273        return turns * (-0.775f - 0.225f * turns) * ((floor & 2L) - 1L);
274    }
275
276    /**
277     * Close approximation of the frequently-used trigonometric method atan2, with higher precision than libGDX's atan2
278     * approximation. Maximum error is below 0.001 radians.
279     * Takes y and x (in that unusual order) as doubles, and returns the angle from the origin to that point in radians.
280     * It is about 5 times faster than {@link Math#atan2(double, double)} (roughly 17 ns instead of roughly 88 ns for
281     * Math, though the computer was under some load during testing). It is almost identical in speed to libGDX'
282     * MathUtils approximation of the same method; MathUtils seems to have worse average error, though.
283     * Credit to Nic Taylor and imuli, with Taylor publishing
284     * <a href="https://www.dsprelated.com/showarticle/1052.php">this nice post</a> and imuli commenting with very
285     * handy information that makes this approach usable. This method changed from an earlier
286     * technique that was twice as fast but had very poor quality, enough to be visually noticeable. See also
287     * {@link #atan2_(double, double)} if you don't want a mess converting to degrees or some other measurement, since
288     * that method returns an angle from 0.0 (equal to 0 degrees) to 1.0 (equal to 360 degrees).
289     * @param y y-component of the point to find the angle towards; note the parameter order is unusual by convention
290     * @param x x-component of the point to find the angle towards; note the parameter order is unusual by convention
291     * @return the angle to the given point, in radians as a double; ranges from -PI to PI
292     */
293    public static double atan2(double y, double x)
294    {
295        if(y == 0.0 && x >= 0.0) return 0.0;
296        double ay = Math.abs(y), ax = Math.abs(x);
297        boolean invert = ay > ax;
298        double z = invert ? ax / ay : ay / ax;
299        z = ((((0.141499  * z) - 0.343315 ) * z - 0.016224 ) * z + 1.003839 ) * z - 0.000158 ;
300        if (invert) z = 1.5707963267948966 - z;
301        if (x < 0) z = 3.141592653589793 - z;
302        return Math.copySign(z, y);
303    }
304
305    /**
306     * Close approximation of the frequently-used trigonometric method atan2, with higher precision than libGDX's atan2
307     * approximation. Maximum error is below 0.001 radians.
308     * Takes y and x (in that unusual order) as floats, and returns the angle from the origin to that point in radians.
309     * It is about 5 times faster than {@link Math#atan2(double, double)} (roughly 17 ns instead of roughly 88 ns for
310     * Math, though the computer was under some load during testing). It is almost identical in speed to libGDX'
311     * MathUtils approximation of the same method; MathUtils seems to have worse average error, though.
312     * Credit to Nic Taylor and imuli, with Taylor publishing
313     * <a href="https://www.dsprelated.com/showarticle/1052.php">this nice post</a> and imuli commenting with very
314     * handy information that makes this approach usable. This method changed from an earlier
315     * technique that was twice as fast but had very poor quality, enough to be visually noticeable. See also
316     * {@link #atan2_(float, float)} if you don't want a mess converting to degrees or some other measurement, since
317     * that method returns an angle from 0f (equal to 0 degrees) to 1f (equal to 360 degrees).
318     * @param y y-component of the point to find the angle towards; note the parameter order is unusual by convention
319     * @param x x-component of the point to find the angle towards; note the parameter order is unusual by convention
320     * @return the angle to the given point, in radians as a float; ranges from -PI to PI
321     */
322    public static float atan2(float y, float x) {
323        if (y == 0f && x >= 0f) return 0f;
324        float ay = Math.abs(y), ax = Math.abs(x);
325        boolean invert = ay > ax;
326        float z = invert ? ax / ay : ay / ax;
327        z = ((((0.141499f * z) - 0.343315f) * z - 0.016224f) * z + 1.003839f) * z - 0.000158f;
328        if (invert) z = 1.5707963267948966f - z;
329        if (x < 0) z = 3.141592653589793f - z;
330        return Math.copySign(z, y);
331    }
332
333    /**
334     * Altered-range approximation of the frequently-used trigonometric method atan2, taking y and x positions as 
335     * doubles and returning an angle measured in turns from 0.0 to 1.0 (inclusive), with one cycle over the range
336     * equivalent to 360 degrees or 2PI radians. You can multiply the angle by {@code 6.2831855f} to change to radians,
337     * or by {@code 360f} to change to degrees. Takes y and x (in that unusual order) as doubles. Will never return a
338     * negative number, which may help avoid costly floating-point modulus when you actually want a positive number.
339     * Credit to Nic Taylor and imuli, with Taylor publishing
340     * <a href="https://www.dsprelated.com/showarticle/1052.php">this nice post</a> and imuli commenting with very
341     * handy information that makes this approach usable. Note that
342     * {@link #atan2(double, double)} returns an angle in radians and can return negative results, which may be fine for
343     * many tasks; these two methods are extremely close in implementation and speed.
344     * @param y y-component of the point to find the angle towards; note the parameter order is unusual by convention
345     * @param x x-component of the point to find the angle towards; note the parameter order is unusual by convention
346     * @return the angle to the given point, as a double from 0.0 to 1.0, inclusive
347     */
348    public static double atan2_(double y, double x)
349    {
350        if(y == 0.0 && x >= 0.0) return 0.0;
351        double ay = Math.abs(y), ax = Math.abs(x);
352        boolean invert = ay > ax;
353        double z = invert ? ax/ay : ay/ax;
354        z = (((((0.022520265292560102) * z) - (0.054640279287594046)) * z - (0.0025821297967229097)) * z + (0.1597659389184251)) * z - (0.000025146481008519463);
355        if(invert) z = 0.25 - z;
356        if(x < 0) z = 0.5 - z;
357        return y < 0 ? (int)(1+z) - z : z;
358
359    }
360    /**
361     * Altered-range approximation of the frequently-used trigonometric method atan2, taking y and x positions as floats
362     * and returning an angle measured in turns from 0.0f to 1.0f, with one cycle over the range equivalent to 360
363     * degrees or 2PI radians. You can multiply the angle by {@code 6.2831855f} to change to radians, or by {@code 360f}
364     * to change to degrees. Takes y and x (in that unusual order) as floats. Will never return a negative number, which
365     * may help avoid costly floating-point modulus when you actually want a positive number.
366     * Credit to Nic Taylor and imuli, with Taylor publishing
367     * <a href="https://www.dsprelated.com/showarticle/1052.php">this nice post</a> and imuli commenting with very
368     * handy information that makes this approach usable. Note that
369     * {@link #atan2(float, float)} returns an angle in radians and can return negative results, which may be fine for
370     * many tasks; these two methods are extremely close in implementation and speed.
371     * @param y y-component of the point to find the angle towards; note the parameter order is unusual by convention
372     * @param x x-component of the point to find the angle towards; note the parameter order is unusual by convention
373     * @return the angle to the given point, as a float from 0.0f to 1.0f, inclusive
374     */
375    public static float atan2_(float y, float x)
376    {
377        if(y == 0.0 && x >= 0.0) return 0f;
378        float ay = Math.abs(y), ax = Math.abs(x);
379        boolean invert = ay > ax;
380        float z = invert ? ax/ay : ay/ax;
381        z = (((((0.022520265292560102f) * z) - (0.054640279287594046f)) * z - (0.0025821297967229097f)) * z + (0.1597659389184251f)) * z - (0.000025146481008519463f);
382        if(invert) z = 0.25f - z;
383        if(x < 0) z = 0.5f - z;
384        return y < 0 ? (int)(1+z) - z : z;
385    }
386
387    /**
388     * Close approximation of the frequently-used trigonometric method atan2, with higher precision than libGDX's atan2
389     * approximation, and giving a result in degrees from -180 to 180. Maximum error is below 0.1 degrees.
390     * Takes y and x (in that unusual order) as doubles, and returns the angle from the origin to that point in degrees.
391     * It is about 5 times faster than {@link Math#atan2(double, double)} (roughly 17 ns instead of roughly 88 ns for
392     * Math, though the computer was under some load during testing). It is almost identical in speed to libGDX'
393     * MathUtils approximation after converting to degrees; MathUtils seems to have worse average error, though.
394     * Credit to Nic Taylor and imuli, with Taylor publishing
395     * <a href="https://www.dsprelated.com/showarticle/1052.php">this nice post</a> and imuli commenting with very
396     * handy information that makes this approach usable.
397     * <br>
398     * See also {@link #atan2Degrees360(double, double)}, which is just like this but returns an angle from 0 to 360,
399     * instead of -180 to 180, in case negative angles are undesirable.
400     * @param y y-component of the point to find the angle towards; note the parameter order is unusual by convention
401     * @param x x-component of the point to find the angle towards; note the parameter order is unusual by convention
402     * @return the angle to the given point, in degrees as a double
403     */
404    public static double atan2Degrees(double y, double x)
405    {
406        if(y == 0.0 && x >= 0.0) return 0.0;
407        double ay = Math.abs(y), ax = Math.abs(x);
408        boolean invert = ay > ax;
409        double z = invert ? ax / ay : ay / ax;
410        z = (((((8.107295505321636)  * z) - (19.670500543533855) ) * z - (0.9295667268202475) ) * z + (57.51573801063304) ) * z - (0.009052733163067006) ;
411        if (invert) z = 90 - z;
412        if (x < 0) z = 180 - z;
413        return Math.copySign(z, y);
414    }
415
416    /**
417     * Close approximation of the frequently-used trigonometric method atan2, with higher precision than libGDX's atan2
418     * approximation, and giving a result in degrees from -180 to 180. Maximum error is below 0.1 degrees.
419     * Takes y and x (in that unusual order) as floats, and returns the angle from the origin to that point in degrees.
420     * It is about 5 times faster than {@link Math#atan2(double, double)} (roughly 17 ns instead of roughly 88 ns for
421     * Math, though the computer was under some load during testing). It is almost identical in speed to libGDX'
422     * MathUtils approximation after converting to degrees; MathUtils seems to have worse average error, though.
423     * Credit to Nic Taylor and imuli, with Taylor publishing
424     * <a href="https://www.dsprelated.com/showarticle/1052.php">this nice post</a> and imuli commenting with very
425     * handy information that makes this approach usable.
426     * <br>
427     * See also {@link #atan2Degrees360(float, float)}, which is just like this but returns an angle from 0 to 360,
428     * instead of -180 to 180, in case negative angles are undesirable.
429     * @param y y-component of the point to find the angle towards; note the parameter order is unusual by convention
430     * @param x x-component of the point to find the angle towards; note the parameter order is unusual by convention
431     * @return the angle to the given point, in degrees as a float
432     */
433    public static float atan2Degrees(float y, float x)
434    {
435        if(y == 0f && x >= 0f) return 0f;
436        float ax = Math.abs(x), ay = Math.abs(y);
437        boolean invert = ay > ax;
438        float z = invert ? ax / ay : ay / ax;
439        z = (((((8.107295505321636f)  * z) - (19.670500543533855f) ) * z - (0.9295667268202475f) ) * z + (57.51573801063304f) ) * z - (0.009052733163067006f) ;
440        if (invert) z = 90 - z;
441        if (x < 0) z = 180 - z;
442        return Math.copySign(z, y);
443    }
444
445    /**
446     * Close approximation of the frequently-used trigonometric method atan2, with higher precision than libGDX's atan2
447     * approximation, and giving a result in degrees from 0 to 360 (both inclusive). Maximum error is below 0.1 degrees.
448     * Takes y and x (in that unusual order) as doubles, and returns the angle from the origin to that point in degrees.
449     * It is about 5 times faster than {@link Math#atan2(double, double)} (roughly 17 ns instead of roughly 88 ns for
450     * Math, though the computer was under some load during testing). It is almost identical in speed to libGDX'
451     * MathUtils approximation after converting to degrees; MathUtils seems to have worse average error, though.
452     * Credit to Nic Taylor and imuli, with Taylor publishing
453     * <a href="https://www.dsprelated.com/showarticle/1052.php">this nice post</a> and imuli commenting with very
454     * handy information that makes this approach usable.
455     * <br>
456     * See also {@link #atan2Degrees(double, double)}, which is just like this but returns an angle from -180 to 180,
457     * matching {@link Math#atan2(double, double)}'s convention.
458     * @param y y-component of the point to find the angle towards; note the parameter order is unusual by convention
459     * @param x x-component of the point to find the angle towards; note the parameter order is unusual by convention
460     * @return the angle to the given point, in degrees as a double
461     */
462    public static double atan2Degrees360(double y, double x)
463    {
464        if(y == 0.0 && x >= 0.0) return 0.0;
465        double ay = Math.abs(y), ax = Math.abs(x);
466        boolean invert = ay > ax;
467        double z = invert ? ax / ay : ay / ax;
468        z = (((((8.107295505321636)  * z) - (19.670500543533855) ) * z - (0.9295667268202475) ) * z + (57.51573801063304) ) * z - (0.009052733163067006) ;
469        if (invert) z = 90 - z;
470        if (x < 0) z = 180 - z;
471        return y < 0 ? 360 - z : z;
472    }
473    /**
474     * Close approximation of the frequently-used trigonometric method atan2, with higher precision than libGDX's atan2
475     * approximation, and giving a result in degrees from 0 to 360 (both inclusive). Maximum error is below 0.1 degrees.
476     * Takes y and x (in that unusual order) as floats, and returns the angle from the origin to that point in degrees.
477     * It is about 5 times faster than {@link Math#atan2(double, double)} (roughly 17 ns instead of roughly 88 ns for
478     * Math, though the computer was under some load during testing). It is almost identical in speed to libGDX'
479     * MathUtils approximation after converting to degrees; MathUtils seems to have worse average error, though.
480     * Credit to Nic Taylor and imuli, with Taylor publishing
481     * <a href="https://www.dsprelated.com/showarticle/1052.php">this nice post</a> and imuli commenting with very
482     * handy information that makes this approach usable.
483     * <br>
484     * See also {@link #atan2Degrees(float, float)}, which is just like this but returns an angle from -180 to 180,
485     * matching {@link Math#atan2(double, double)}'s convention.
486     * @param y y-component of the point to find the angle towards; note the parameter order is unusual by convention
487     * @param x x-component of the point to find the angle towards; note the parameter order is unusual by convention
488     * @return the angle to the given point, in degrees as a float
489     */
490    public static float atan2Degrees360(float y, float x)
491    {
492        if(y == 0f && x >= 0f) return 0f;
493        float ax = Math.abs(x), ay = Math.abs(y);
494        boolean invert = ay > ax;
495        float z = invert ? ax / ay : ay / ax;
496        z = (((((8.107295505321636f)  * z) - (19.670500543533855f) ) * z - (0.9295667268202475f) ) * z + (57.51573801063304f) ) * z - (0.009052733163067006f) ;
497        if (invert) z = 90 - z;
498        if (x < 0) z = 180 - z;
499        return y < 0 ? 360 - z : z;
500    }
501
502    /**
503     * Arc sine approximation with very low error, using an algorithm from the 1955 research study
504     * "Approximations for Digital Computers," by RAND Corporation (this is sheet 35's algorithm, which is the fastest
505     * and least precise). This method is usually much faster than {@link Math#asin(double)}, but is somewhat less
506     * precise than Math's implementation. It is currently much more precise than libGDX's approximation in their
507     * MathUtils, and is a little faster.
508     * <br>
509     * Accuracy: absolute error 0.000028447, relative error -0.000000033, max error 0.000067592 .
510     * @param x an input to the inverse sine function, from -1 to 1 inclusive
511     * @return an output from the inverse sine function, from PI/-2.0 to PI/2.0 inclusive.
512     */
513    public static double asin(final double x) {
514        final double x2 = x * x;
515        final double x3 = x * x2;
516        if (x >= 0.0) {
517            return 1.5707963267948966 - Math.sqrt(1.0 - x) *
518                    (1.5707288 - 0.2121144 * x + 0.0742610 * x2 - 0.0187293 * x3);
519        }
520        else {
521            return -1.5707963267948966 + Math.sqrt(1.0 + x) *
522                    (1.5707288 + 0.2121144 * x + 0.0742610 * x2 + 0.0187293 * x3);
523        }
524    }
525    /**
526     * Arc cosine approximation with very low error, using an algorithm from the 1955 research study
527     * "Approximations for Digital Computers," by RAND Corporation (this is sheet 35's algorithm, which is the fastest
528     * and least precise). This method is usually much faster than {@link Math#acos(double)}, but is somewhat less
529     * precise than Math's implementation. It is currently much more precise than libGDX's approximation in their
530     * MathUtils, and is a little faster.
531     * @param x an input to the inverse cosine function, from -1 to 1 inclusive
532     * @return an output from the inverse cosine function, from 0 to PI inclusive.
533     */
534    public static double acos(final double x) {
535        final double x2 = x * x;
536        final double x3 = x * x2;
537        if (x >= 0.0) {
538            return Math.sqrt(1.0 - x) * (1.5707288 - 0.2121144 * x + 0.0742610 * x2 - 0.0187293 * x3);
539        }
540        else {
541            return 3.14159265358979323846 - Math.sqrt(1.0 + x) * (1.5707288 + 0.2121144 * x + 0.0742610 * x2 + 0.0187293 * x3);
542        }
543    }
544    /**
545     * Inverse sine function (arcsine) but with output measured in turns instead of radians. Possible results for this
546     * range from 0.75 (inclusive) to 1.0 (exclusive), and continuing past that to 0.0 (inclusive) to 0.25 (inclusive).
547     * <br>
548     * This method is extremely similar to the non-turn approximation.
549     * @param x a double from -1.0 to 1.0 (both inclusive), usually the output of sin_() or cos_()
550     * @return one of the values that would produce {@code n} if it were passed to {@link #sin_(double)}
551     */
552    public static double asin_(final double x)
553    {
554        final double x2 = x * x;
555        final double x3 = x * x2;
556        if (x >= 0.0) {
557            return 0.25 - Math.sqrt(1.0 - x) *
558                    (0.24998925277680106 - 0.033759055260971525 * x + 0.01181900522894724 * x2 - 0.0029808606756510357 * x3);
559        }
560        else {
561            return 0.75 + Math.sqrt(1.0 + x) *
562                    (0.24998925277680106 + 0.033759055260971525 * x + 0.01181900522894724 * x2 + 0.0029808606756510357 * x3);
563        }
564    }
565    /**
566     * Inverse cosine function (arccos) but with output measured in turns instead of radians. Possible results for this
567     * range from 0.0 (inclusive) to 0.5 (inclusive).
568     * <br>
569     * This method is extremely similar to the non-turn approximation.
570     * @param x a double from -1.0 to 1.0 (both inclusive), usually the output of sin_() or cos_()
571     * @return one of the values that would produce {@code n} if it were passed to {@link #cos_(double)}
572     */
573    public static double acos_(final double x)
574    {
575        final double x2 = x * x;
576        final double x3 = x * x2;
577        if (x >= 0.0) {
578            return Math.sqrt(1.0 - x) * (0.24998925277680106 - 0.033759055260971525 * x + 0.01181900522894724 * x2 - 0.0029808606756510357 * x3);
579        }
580        else {
581            return 0.5 - Math.sqrt(1.0 + x) * (0.24998925277680106 + 0.033759055260971525 * x + 0.01181900522894724 * x2 + 0.0029808606756510357 * x3);
582        }
583    }
584
585
586    /**
587     * Inverse sine function (arcsine) but with output measured in turns instead of radians. Possible results for this
588     * range from 0.75f (inclusive) to 1.0f (exclusive), and continuing past that to 0.0f (inclusive) to 0.25f
589     * (inclusive).
590     * <br>
591     * This method is extremely similar to the non-turn approximation.
592     * @param x a float from -1.0f to 1.0f (both inclusive), usually the output of sin_() or cos_()
593     * @return one of the values that would produce {@code n} if it were passed to {@link #sin_(float)}
594     */
595    public static float asin_(final float x)
596    {
597        final float x2 = x * x;
598        final float x3 = x * x2;
599        if (x >= 0f) {
600            return 0.25f - (float) Math.sqrt(1f - x) *
601                    (0.24998925277680106f - 0.033759055260971525f * x + 0.01181900522894724f * x2 - 0.0029808606756510357f * x3);
602        }
603        else {
604            return 0.75f + (float) Math.sqrt(1f + x) *
605                    (0.24998925277680106f + 0.033759055260971525f * x + 0.01181900522894724f * x2 + 0.0029808606756510357f * x3);
606        }
607    }
608    /**
609     * Inverse cosine function (arccos) but with output measured in turns instead of radians. Possible results for this
610     * range from 0.0f (inclusive) to 0.5f (inclusive).
611     * <br>
612     * This method is extremely similar to the non-turn approximation.
613     * @param x a float from -1.0f to 1.0f (both inclusive), usually the output of sin_() or cos_()
614     * @return one of the values that would produce {@code n} if it were passed to {@link #cos_(float)}
615     */
616    public static float acos_(final float x)
617    {
618        final float x2 = x * x;
619        final float x3 = x * x2;
620        if (x >= 0f) {
621            return (float) Math.sqrt(1f - x) * (0.24998925277680106f - 0.033759055260971525f * x + 0.01181900522894724f * x2 - 0.0029808606756510357f * x3);
622        }
623        else {
624            return 0.5f - (float) Math.sqrt(1f + x) * (0.24998925277680106f + 0.033759055260971525f * x + 0.01181900522894724f * x2 + 0.0029808606756510357f * x3);
625        }
626    }
627}
